content.description: From the obvious cave, climb up and left to an easy topout. Two options: stand start with a left undercling and a good right hold, or sit two moves below (which makes it more of a solid V7). The rock quality is not great, but the movement is good once you figure it out.

Grand Pianist is a good looking line with a questionable landing. I have not tried it yet, but I believe that Adam Markert sent it a few years back and called it V9. Both of those statements could be wrong. If you know better, add comments, and I'll update.
content.location:
From the

unknown cave problem

, continue up and left 30 feet. The route faces downhill.

content.description:
Cardiac Arrest ascends steep, solid crimps on okay rock coming out a cave. We started on a good, left sidepull below the lip and a bad, right crimp also below. A move or two establishes you above the small shelf, and then it is straightforward steep crimping on decent edges. You could start a bit lower - that appears to be significantly harder. I was told it is V6, thought it could be easy for that, so V5/6 it is for now.

It does seem a little sketchy with the rock behind you, but with a pad and a spot, I think it is safe.
content.location: This is at the far right side of the boulderfield. Find the Big Ass Boulder (basically above Euro) and walk to the back of it. From there, go straight up to the cliff line (it is not far, but it is a little overgrown), and look to your right. Cardiac Arrest is sitting in a small cave.
